ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 10 hours
3-4 hours
~1-3 on weekly homework assignments
3-5 hours
2 hours.
2-3 hours
4 hours
2 hours per week
About 3-4 hours
5 hours
4-6 hours per week
1 hour per week, plus extra hours for exam weeks
3-4hours
10 hours a week
6 hours

It varied. If we were taught material that some of us learned elsewhere, then the hours per week spent on that assignment was too too bads. Sometimes we had homework assignments on material that either was not taught, or was poorly taught. During those weeks, the homework assignments could have easily take more than 6-10 hours.
4-5hrs
4 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good!
Pretty low pressure. Some topics are more interesting than others but you get through. He tries to give anecdotes to make the class more fun.
Seems a bit disorganized at times and the homework assignments don't always line up with the lectures.

The lectures were very interesting and provided lots of good information. But the lack of fundamental knowledge became a huge problem for the first year students as me. As I know, many students did not take any clinical trails class before.
I thought the course was an extremely interesting to the idea and practice of clinical trials

Strengths:-Nice overview of issues relating to clinical trials-Incorporated topics relating to health policy, biostats, and study design-Required text was very readable-glad I own it now!-Excellent TA and instructor (see below)Weaknesses:-Class size was too large, preventing discussion on potentially interesting topics-powerpoints/lectures were not well organized and often repetitive-Overall, a lot of overlap with Survival Analysis (BIS 630b)and Design of Epi Studies (BIS 632b). I'm not sure why my degree program required me to take both?!Areas for improvement:-Provide more "real world examples" in class and in homework reading to apply concepts-Either limit class size or have discussion groups to allow for more discussion on topics
The homework assignments were helpful for practicing the concepts learned in class.
Great course. Very helpful.
The materials are very interesting and helpful.The lecture is too long that is more than 2 hours. It was hard to focus on every min.
good

This was a nice overview of the major principles of clinical trials. A lot of the material was a review of things we learned in Biostatistics II and Epidemiology II, but it was helpful to learn that material again. Overall, it was a low-key and low-stress course and I feel like I got a lot out of it.
Very informatve

The second half of the semester covered many models and data treatment for clinical trials which heavily involved the statistical program. However, there is no lab session for this class which make this part difficult. It's better not to cover longitudinal data analysis. One lecture doesn't help that much.

This course was very interesting, but during the second half of the course, I do not think the professor explained the mathematical components of the course at all; I think he assumed we knew it. This was very confusing to figure out for someone who is not a biostatistics student.
very good coverage of topics in clinical trials.
The class and instructor are nice but the class materials (presentation slides) are not well organized especially for quantitative theme.

Strengths - interesting material, good TA, not that difficult of a course at all, only once a week, good professor with interesting personal anecdotes, easy homework, open notes exams, interesting guest lecturersWeaknesses - didn't feel challenged, did not feel like i learned half as much during the second half of the semester, lectures were very repetitive and did not get a lot out of themImprovements - we should go over in class how to do what we learned to do in SAS code in hand-written form. When it came time to study for final exam, I did not know where to start. We were not using SAS during the final, but we had to do it by hand - I had to go to the TA to learn all of this.
The course is great! A lot of useful examples and good explanation of key concepts.
The content is flexible, and you can learn a lot if you are interested in Clinic Trials

The strength of this course was the weekly homework assignments. They really helped me to understand what was being taught in class. Overall I learned a lot from this class and I really appreciate how Dr. Makuch explained what goes on in clinical trials from his personal experience.
Didn't learn very much.

Lectures are interesting, but not clearly that useful for people who are not interested in the process of clinical trials. Survival analysis is useful, but taught in many other classes. Does not seem like it should be a required class.

This course could be improved with clearer lectures. The topics seemed to skip around quite a bit. While studying for the final it was helpful independently compiling pieces of information about survival analysis over the last 4 lectures. It would have been much easier if each piece of the topic was throughly and completely discussed, rather than bits and pieces that need to be gleaned from the slides over multiple lectures.
Very informative, at times too detailed and hard to grasp concepts.

New knowledge provided in this course is very limited beyond Epi I and II. Being a course from the stats department, it might be better for this course to give more emphasis to statistical methods used in clinical trials
I really like this course and the content is very applicable for my career interest.

Since it is a BIS class, I expected it to focus more on the statistical elements in clinical trials. However, the professor actually spent a lot time talking about ethical issues and regulatory issues. I don't think I learned as much skills as I expected from this course.
excellent

The course is taught by an extreme nice professor who wants everyone to do well. This course is great for those who have an extensive mathematical background. But the overall course was poorly taught. I had to rely upon the help of others who were free to go to the TA sessions or those who has previously seen the material to learn what was going on.
Strenght: real world examplesWeakness: too much statistics
Some slides were a little confusing when trying to do the math/formulas.
I felt I had to teach myself most of the material. A lot of the homework didn't seem to be covered in class.

The concepts taught are very applicable to all public health students and physicians. The book provided a good foundation and was not too detailed to read. I would have liked the professor to explain in detail more and go through more in class examples of the math part of the class.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Robert Makuch  Good!
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He includes anecdotes to make lecture more fun. Sometimes he takes a while to get through lectures - they could get done a lot faster. But overall he's a good professor.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Really knows the material and seems to care about the students.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  very knowledgeable and care about students

Instructor: Robert Makuch  I thought the instructor did a great job introducing and explaining the concepts of clinical trials. I really enjoyed how he used his personal experiences in the industry, as well as his knowledge of various trials, to provide numerous examples and to illustrate the complexity of the design and analysis of clinical trials.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch was excellent. His breadth of experience and perspectives were refreshingly honest. I loved listening to his anecdotes of working at the NCI years ago! The homework and exams were very clearly written and covered key topics. Dr. Ciarleglio lectured a couple of times as well- she was fabulous, as always.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The lectures were somewhat hard to follow because of the multiple tangents and anecdotes.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor gives interesting topics during class.The lecture notes could be more organized.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very helpful professor, not boring teaching style, and I like the examples he gave in the lecture.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  good instructor
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He's a pretty cool guy. I enjoyed his personal anecdotes, and overall I really liked his teaching style.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The professor really knows what he is talking about.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch definitely knows many stories in the area. I hope he can cover more content in the text book and not just make us read it by ourselves. add some examples when talking about the calculations in Kaplan-Meier curves.Maria is excellent. the slides is well organized and the lecture is clear and coherent.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is a very friendly and approachable professor. Unfortunately, he does not respond to e-mails, so sometimes it can be difficult to reach him outside of class.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  explains material very clearly. would be better if the slides are more organized.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Good personality.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Prof. Makuch is a great person and a pretty good lecturer. He has really funny and interesting anecdotes, and he is very very successful in his field. While he does not have time to really get to know his students well (he was nice enough to host a end of semester party for us, but left within the first 15 min), I liked him. Heis often very repetitive in his lectures and does not explain things well. He is very fair in terms of readings, homeworks, and exams. That being said, I had to rely on the TA to teach me things that I needed to know, but did not get out of the lecture.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is great! He brings a lot of life examples, which provides a very good explanation to the concepts and principles.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He is knowledgeable and engaged in the class.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch was good at explaining the basics of clinical trials and providing practical examples where necessary.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very friendly, nice person.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch was very enthusiastic, and clearly has an encyclopedic knowledge of the subject.He has a tendency to go off-topic, but that keeps the lectures interesting. It's not always clear what we are supposed to get out of the lectures.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Good instructor - sometimes hard to follow in class during tangents
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Sometimes hard to follow, would be very helpful if he stayed on track more with lectures. Very nice man though and it is clear he cares about his students!
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Great professor, very understanding and caring. Would definitely take another course with him in the future if i can.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor is very friendly and has a lot of experience in the subject matter. Might be improved from adhering more tightly to main course materials.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  The professor is very good at giving us real-life examples and the guest lecturer is also very good at teaching complicated math.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  I love this professor! Provided very interesting stories during lecture, and gave students plenty of time and space to fully understand the material. I learned a great deal and the exams were very informative and reflective of materials taught.

Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor is very kind and is willing to answer questions. The main problem was that he is so smart that he didn't realize that the majority of what he taught, was dificult, especially to those who had limited maths backgrounds. There were some lectures were he barley got through teaching because he kept being interrupted by questions from students. He is very nice guy, but needs to make the class more easy to follow for those who don't have a Phd in biostats.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Very kind and knowledgeable.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He offered interesting anecdotes in class, but I just didn't think he addressed our questions about the homework well.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  See above.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Good!
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was helpful at times. I wish she were more helpful with the homework at answering questions.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Very responsible and willing to help students

Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was the best TA I've had in my past couple of years at EPH. She responded quickly to emails and distributed class information (homework assignments, answer keys, exam info, etc.) very efficiently. On the day she reviewed the midterm, she explained the questions, answers, and grading well.My only suggestion would be that, on the day she gave a lecture, I wish she had done so with her own powerpoint slides, rather than just reading from Dr. Makuch's.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel is very helpful in giving timely response to question.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was very helpful and quick to answer our questions and help us.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Very helpful in class and outside class.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  responsible
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  - Rachel was great and provided very useful feedback on all the HW's.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel is great.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel is good and always respond to my email.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was a helpful TA. She replied promptly to e-mails and was always there to answer any questions.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  responded very quickly to questions and emails.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Really nice TA.

Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was great! She was easily available by office hours, and because not many people took advantage of them, I was able to get great help from her when I did go. She explained things well, and prepared me well for the exams.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Very helpful.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Wonderful
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Rachel was a great TA and provided good feedback on our homework. The class she taught on survival analysis was very well taught.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Good job
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  There were no separate discussion sections, but Rachel was able to provide feedback on homework assignments and answer questions.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  She was great. Always quick with emails about questions and answered them well.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Didn't have much interaction with her, but homework comments were helpful
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Great, very helpful.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Our TA is very responsible.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  excellent TA.

Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  The few times I saw the TA, she was helpful. She did a good job of helping us understand what the instructor was talking about. She had to teach one class which she taught in an understanding way. I wish she had more office hours on more days for those with really busy schedules.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Very kind and helpful.
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  not much hw feedback
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  Good at responding to questions
Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  She was responsive to our questions.

Instructor: Rachel Heejin Bhak  I felt the TA at times was helpful but also somewhat afraid to really instruct and teach some of the more difficult concepts. She seemed nice enough but did not seem to have either a lot of confidence or experience.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Good!
I would recommend it if you're either interested in clinical trials or are looking for a low-pressure class.
I would recommend it. Very useful for further studies and researches.

I think the course is a great introduction to clinical trials for people of various disciplines. Basic statistics principles are discussed, but the course is accessible to many students outside of biostatistics as well.

Clinical Trials gives a broad overview of issues relating to study design, protocol development (e.g. sample size calculations), and analysis of survival studies. A nice and relatively easy course work load-wise but repetitive if you have already taken BIS 630b or BIS 632b. If nothing else, take the course for Dr. Makuch's anecdotes from his years at NCI and serving on DSMBs.
Relevant if you are interested in developing clinical trials- in particular the first half of the course was full of good conceptual material.
Yes, this course provides useful knowledge of clinical trails to beginners.
I will recommend. This course is a fundamental one, and it is very helpful for the future public health study. I learned how to set up clinical trials and many useful statistics knowledge.

I honestly took this class just because I needed a 5th class and wanted something that did not have a heavy workload or high stress level. This was the perfect class for that, and I felt like I learned a lot.
Intro course to clinical trial. Recommended to students who are interested in doing clinical research.
I will recommend this course to student if you want to know something about clinical trials but be prepared to learn it by yourself through the assigned reading and not just listen to the lectures.
I would definitely recommended it to others. I learned a lot about clinical trials. Would be better if can bring people working in this field--such as FDA, pharmaceutical companies.
Recommend this class but need extra self study

A good biostats course for non-biostats concentration who need the course requirement. It's not a big time commitment - only once a week with easy homeworks due each week. The lecture is alright, the professor is pretty interesting and has good anecdotes. You should understand that it will take time outside of the lecture to teach yourself some things, because they're not nicely laid out in the lecture.
I would recommend this course to everyone interested in clinical trials or interventions research.
You can take it if you have no knowledge of what clincal trial is.
This was a great class and I learned a lot about clinical trials that I wouldn't have learned on my own. I highly recommend it to other students.
Nice option for a stats requirement that won't crush your soul.

This course provides a lot of information about how a drug goes through the process of clinical trials (focusing on stage 3) and approval by the FDA.You learn about randomization processes, study designs, and data analysis with a focus on survival analysis.
Yes recommend
Yes would recommend. Very informative and relevant to MPH.
It is an entry-level, comprehensive course for student who has no background and knowledge in clinical trials at all.
very practical and useful content if you are interested in the pharmaceutical industry, this is a highly recommended course.
If you have taken Epi I and II, then this class have little to add in terms of concepts and statistical methods.

If the teaching remains the same, I would only recommend this course to those who really know biostats well. This class felt very fast and didn't feel like it was a class for those with beginners knowledge of biostats. But, for those who told me they asked many questions to the professor after class, I was told that he did a good job of clarifying misunderstandings.
Great easy course
I would recommend this class.
It is helpful information I will probably use in the future to evaluate clinical trials.
I think overall it is worth taking but just be prepared to do a lot is self instruction.
